text: Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging.

text: Patient: No. Doctor: but it’s just, you know, we obsess about numbers. So, we’re like, “GAHHHH, where’d the platelets go?” And, that’s that. Appetite loss… Family Member: Ohhhh… (laughter) Doctor: Can occur which we can only pray for. Doctor: I would say that’s about it. I mean, in terms of what I really see people feeling bad about. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the fatigue, you know, for somebody like you who is on the go constantly could be significant. Like, I don’t want to minimize that in the . You have Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted? Doctor: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her. Patient: Uh I don’t think Family Member 1: She’s two years old. He lifts her up the crib. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: But we're worried can she get cancer from him? Like from being around him? Doctor: No, she can't get sick from him.

text: Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. So let me, um yeah, so this is the so this is the part that's part of the research that's going to be free of charge. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
